intro: Tanarius motleyanus, commonly known as the Motley's tanarius, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, velvety leaves and showy, pentagonal flowers. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments, often in forest understories. Its flowers, which bloom in late spring, are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. Due to habitat loss, Tanarius motleyanus is considered endangered and is the subject of conservation efforts.
